answer is housing policy which sounds like a little bit of a non Secor but um
I I've been a software engineer for a while uh since since I graduated college but in my free time I was doing a lot of
a lot of hous policy work in San Francisco trying to get us to build more and um I will hold off on ranting about

know that he had like a super technical open source background anything like that um and uh so I I really respected

was like oh that's interesting the plot thickens yeah so I I reached out to him
and uh we started talking and I I had all these ideas about what GitHub should do I sent him an email being like GitHub
should help open source maintainers they should do all these things for communities they should build better tools and he sort of boomeranged it back
to me and was like yeah I agree how about you come join us how you how about you come do it and um because I had had
that experience working in some nonprofits with him I knew that he was both a really effective person but also a really good person uh and I just
jumped at the opportunity to work with him I think when when I sent the email I did with all my ideas I didn't really
expect him to have that response that was not I was not looking for a job but as soon as he sort of framed it that way

when you arrived there it was probably just a a bunch of ideas and there's so many different routes to go first of all
why opinions yeah exactly oh yeah I would be kind of scared to tackle such a
problem because things can go wrong what what why is this a problem that you were specifically interested in what what
part of your background I mean I know you mentioned your kind of your activism in your local government but what else
makes like sustainability and maintainers something you're like I would quit what I'm currently doing and go to work on this and then what kind of
ideas did you have about it so this is going to get a little abstract for a moment but the the kinds of problems I'm
really interested in are what I call coordination problems uh if you remember from your econ 101 years there's like uh
prisoners dilemmas and tragedies of the commons and those sort of things where um basically the the thing that they all
have in common is that there's a lot of individuals who are operating on their own best interest and trying to do the
right thing um but the result is that they all sort of fail so the the the classic example of this is like climate
change where no one wants the planet to melt and burn to a crisp um but everyone
individually benefits a little bit more from taking that longer shower or driving to work instead of biking um and
so the result is that everybody ends up worse off uh and if they're not able to coordinate for sort of the greater good
there and um so housing policy has this shape too where um nobody really wants
building to live in their backyard they don't want a big skyscraper but at the same time people do want housing to be
affordable across the city they just don't want it to be in their backyard and so it's sort of that's sort of a
coordination problem and so bringing this to open source we all want amazing open source software we all want this
infrastructure that we can build on top of um but it's sort of hard for any one of us to pay for it it's it's hard to
justify why you are the one person who shells out 10 bucks a month um to to
support open source that everyone else is just using for free uh Wikipedia is also an instance of this where millions
and millions of people use it every single day probably even more than that actually I don't know T tons of people use Wikipedia and everyone benefits from
it if it disappeared the world would definitely be a worse place we would have less access to information um but
the vast majority of Wikipedia users don't pay for it so that shape of problem really really frustrates me and
makes me sad um and I thought that get Hub was really the only place that could
significantly change that that equation for open source um because it's the home where all open source developers live
and GitHub ultimately is built on top of Open Source and depends on these communities um and so the company has a
really strong motivation I think to to try to solve this problem for everybody can you peel back the layers to how you
think about a problem like this do you think about it from the I heard this this uh term recently the three-year
plan essentially the threee problem where instead of thinking about what you're going to do today as I've got to
succeed tomorrow it's more like I got to succeed 3 years from now how do you sort of Peel back the layers of this very
deep very hard problem and solve it I guess iteratively over time how do you
approach it iteratively is absolutely the way we have to approach it the Paradigm that we've been building open
source in for a long time um has had some great strengths it also has some
clear weaknesses in my view where we we aren't fun the work that needs to happen uh and we're right now we're at Point a
and we want to go to point B but if we immediately jump to point B that could actually shake up the the Paradigm
that's actually working pretty well and you end up sort of worse in both situations um so we are working
iteratively to put small changes out at a time make sure they're actually working testing them um and then sort of
moving moving that that edge a little bit further out towards towards point B so concretely what this means is uh in
in may we launched the beta of GitHub sponsors and um we could we could have in theory you know just said everyone

getting a lot of positive feedback from users um we we did make some adjustments
to to make sure things worked better for people before rolling it out and we can
we plan to continue taking this really incremental approach approach where we do one small thing at a time um as
opposed to totally changing it and one final thing I'll say about that is what
we've done so far I'm really proud of the the work of the whole team but we have a lot more to do um if we if we

um there sort of a theoretical reason some some some of the one of the models that I created during my research was
this recognition that because it is so easy to start a new open source project
which is again one of the biggest strengths of it anyone can just go and create a repo and start sharing their code it also it often means that people
um haven't put much thought into how to govern the project who is the owner of
the project um who get to say who which stakeholders get to be part of the decision and it's to sort of go back to
the the city planning metaphor um it's if you're if you were creating a a
physical infrastructure project you would have to answer all of those questions before you were even allowed to get started right like if I want to
build a new freeway I don't get to just go start building a new freeway whenever I want um I have to get permits from the
city I have to raise funding I have to create a charter I have to create a business plan of like how all this stuff
and then maybe I get to start building my highway um open source doesn't have that which is a great blessing but it
means that when these projects do get funding they often uh haven't really
thought about those implications so with the weit list questions we're we're sort of prompting those questions to be like
hey uh do you have answers to these if you haven't maybe you should consider them before you start accepting uh
